segment_text: The last question was asked for the first time, half in jest, on May 21, 2061, at a time when humanity first stepped into the light.
scene_description: Futuristic Earth cityscape, solar power station orbiting Earth, distant moon.

segment_text: The question came about as a result of a five-dollar bet over highballs, and it happened this way:
scene_description: Futuristic Earth cityscape, solar power station orbiting Earth, distant moon.

segment_text: Alexander Adell and Bertram Lupov were two of the faithful attendants of Multivac.
scene_description: Futuristic Earth cityscape, solar power station orbiting Earth, distant moon.

segment_text: As well as any human beings could, they knew what lay behind the cold, clicking, flashing face -- miles and miles of face -- of that giant computer.
scene_description: Futuristic Earth cityscape, solar power station orbiting Earth, distant moon.

segment_text: They had at least a vague notion of the general plan of relays and circuits that had long since grown past the point where any single human could possibly have a firm grasp of the whole.
scene_description: Futuristic Earth cityscape, solar power station orbiting Earth, distant moon.

segment_text: Multivac was self-adjusting and self-correcting. It had to be, for nothing human could adjust and correct it quickly enough or even adequately enough.
scene_description: Futuristic Earth cityscape, solar power station orbiting Earth, distant moon.

segment_text: So Adell and Lupov attended the monstrous giant only lightly and superficially, yet as well as any men could. They fed it data, adjusted questions to its needs and translated the answers that were issued.
scene_description: Futuristic Earth cityscape, solar power station orbiting Earth, distant moon.

segment_text: Certainly they, and all others like them, were fully entitled to share in the glory that was Multivac's.
scene_description: Futuristic Earth cityscape, solar power station orbiting Earth, distant moon.

segment_text: For decades, Multivac had helped design the ships and plot the trajectories that enabled man to reach the Moon, Mars, and Venus, but past that, Earth's poor resources could not support the ships.
scene_description: Futuristic Earth cityscape, solar power station orbiting Earth, distant moon.

segment_text: Too much energy was needed for the long trips. Earth exploited its coal and uranium with increasing efficiency, but there was only so much of both.
scene_description: Futuristic Earth cityscape, solar power station orbiting Earth, distant moon.

segment_text: But slowly Multivac learned enough to answer deeper questions more fundamentally, and on May 14, 2061, what had been theory, became fact.
scene_description: Futuristic Earth cityscape, solar power station orbiting Earth, distant moon.

segment_text: The energy of the sun was stored, converted, and utilized directly on a planet-wide scale.
scene_description: Futuristic Earth cityscape, solar power station orbiting Earth, distant moon.

segment_text: All Earth turned off its burning coal, its fissioning uranium, and flipped the switch that connected all of it to a small station, one mile in diameter, circling the Earth at half the distance of the Moon. All Earth ran by invisible beams of sunpower.
scene_description: Futuristic Earth cityscape, solar power station orbiting Earth, distant moon.

segment_text: Seven days had not sufficed to dim the glory of it and Adell and Lupov finally managed to escape from the public functions, and to meet in quiet where no one would think of looking for them, in the deserted underground chambers, where portions of the mighty buried body of Multivac showed.
scene_description: Indoors, deserted underground chamber, exposed computer components, blinking lights.

segment_text: Unattended, idling, sorting data with contented lazy clickings, Multivac, too, had earned its vacation and the boys appreciated that. They had no intention, originally, of disturbing it.
scene_description: Indoors, deserted underground chamber, exposed computer components, blinking lights.

segment_text: They had brought a bottle with them, and their only concern at the moment was to relax in the company of each other and the bottle. "It's amazing when you think of it," said Adell.
scene_description: Indoors, deserted underground chamber, exposed computer components, blinking lights.

segment_text: His broad face had lines of weariness in it, and he stirred his drink slowly with a glass rod, watching the cubes of ice slur clumsily about. "All the energy we can possibly ever use for free.
scene_description: Indoors, deserted underground chamber, exposed computer components, blinking lights.

segment_text: Enough energy, if we wanted to draw on it, to melt all Earth into a big drop of impure liquid iron, and still never miss the energy so used. All the energy we could ever use, forever and forever and forever." Lupov cocked his head sideways.
scene_description: Indoors, deserted underground chamber, exposed computer components, blinking lights.

segment_text: He had a trick of doing that when he wanted to be contrary, and he wanted to be contrary now, partly because he had had to carry the ice and glassware. "Not forever," he said.
scene_description: Indoors, deserted underground chamber, exposed computer components, blinking lights.

segment_text: "Oh, hell, just about forever. Till the sun runs down, Bert." "That's not forever."
scene_description: Indoors, deserted underground chamber, exposed computer components, blinking lights.

segment_text: "All right, then. Billions and billions of years. Ten billion, maybe. Are you satisfied?"
scene_description: Indoors, deserted underground chamber, exposed computer components, blinking lights.

segment_text: Lupov put his fingers through his thinning hair as though to reassure himself that some was still left and sipped gently at his own drink. "Ten billion years isn't forever."
scene_description: Indoors, deserted underground chamber, exposed computer components, blinking lights.

segment_text: "Well, it will last our time, won't it?" "So would the coal and uranium."
scene_description: Indoors, deserted underground chamber, exposed computer components, blinking lights.

segment_text: "All right, but now we can hook up each individual spaceship to the Solar Station, and it can go to Pluto and back a million times without ever worrying about fuel. You can't do that on coal and uranium. Ask Multivac, if you don't believe me."
scene_description: Indoors, deserted underground chamber, exposed computer components, blinking lights.

segment_text: "I don't have to ask Multivac. I know that." "Then stop running down what Multivac's done for us," said Adell, blazing up, "It did all right."
scene_description: Indoors, deserted underground chamber, exposed computer components, blinking lights.

segment_text: "Who says it didn't? What I say is that a sun won't last forever. That's all I'm saying. We're safe for ten billion years, but then what?"
scene_description: Indoors, deserted underground chamber, exposed computer components, blinking lights.

segment_text: Lupow pointed a slightly shaky finger at the other. "And don't say we'll switch to another sun."
scene_description: Indoors, deserted underground chamber, exposed computer components, blinking lights.

segment_text: There was silence for a while. Adell put his glass to his lips only occasionally, and Lupov's eyes slowly closed. They rested.
scene_description: Indoors, deserted underground chamber, exposed computer components, blinking lights.

segment_text: Then Lupov's eyes snapped open. "You're thinking we'll switch to another sun when ours is done, aren't you?" "I'm not thinking."
scene_description: Indoors, deserted underground chamber, exposed computer components, blinking lights.

segment_text: "Sure you are. You're weak on logic, that's the trouble with you. You're like the guy in the story who was caught in a sudden shower and who ran to a grove of trees and got under one. He wasn't worried, you see, because he figured when one tree got wet through, he would just get under another one."
scene_description: Indoors, deserted underground chamber, exposed computer components, blinking lights.

segment_text: "I get it," said Adell. "Don't shout. When the sun is done, the other stars will be gone, too." "Darn right they will," muttered Lupov.
scene_description: Indoors, deserted underground chamber, exposed computer components, blinking lights.

segment_text: "It all had a beginning in the original cosmic explosion, whatever that was, and it'll all have an end when all the stars run down. Some run down faster than others. Hell, the giants won't last a hundred million years."
scene_description: Indoors, deserted underground chamber, exposed computer components, blinking lights.

segment_text: "The sun will last ten billion years and maybe the dwarfs will last two hundred billion for all the good they are. But just give us a trillion years and everything will be dark. Entropy has to increase to maximum, that's all."
scene_description: Indoors, deserted underground chamber, exposed computer components, blinking lights.

segment_text: "I know all about entropy," said Adell, standing on his dignity. "The hell you do." "I know as much as you do."
scene_description: Indoors, deserted underground chamber, exposed computer components, blinking lights.

segment_text: "Then you know everything's got to run down someday." "All right. Who says they won't?" "You did, you poor sap. You said we had all the energy we needed, forever. You said 'forever.'"
scene_description: Indoors, deserted underground chamber, exposed computer components, blinking lights.

segment_text: It was Adell's turn to be contrary. "Maybe we can build things up again someday," he said. "Never." "Why not? Someday." "Never."
scene_description: Indoors, deserted underground chamber, exposed computer components, blinking lights.

segment_text: "Ask Multivac." "You ask Multivac. I dare you. Five dollars says it can't be done."
scene_description: Indoors, deserted underground chamber, exposed computer components, blinking lights.

segment_text: Adell was just drunk enough to try, just sober enough to be able to phrase the necessary symbols and operations into a question which, in words, might have corresponded to this: Will mankind one day without the net expenditure of energy be able to restore the sun to its full youthfulness even after it had died of old age?
scene_description: Indoors, deserted underground chamber, exposed computer components, blinking lights.

segment_text: Or maybe it could be put more simply like this: How can the net amount of entropy of the universe be massively decreased? Multivac fell dead and silent.
scene_description: Indoors, deserted underground chamber, exposed computer components, blinking lights.

segment_text: The slow flashing of lights ceased, the distant sounds of clicking relays ended. Then, just as the frightened technicians felt they could hold their breath no longer, there was a sudden springing to life of the teletype attached to that portion of Multivac.
scene_description: Indoors, deserted underground chamber, exposed computer components, blinking lights.

segment_text: Five words were printed: INSUFFICIENT DATA FOR MEANINGFUL ANSWER. "No bet," whispered Lupov. They left hurriedly.
scene_description: Indoors, deserted underground chamber, exposed computer components, blinking lights.

segment_text: By next morning, the two, plagued with throbbing head and cottony mouth, had forgotten the incident.
scene_description: Indoors, deserted underground chamber, exposed computer components, blinking lights.

segment_text: Jerrodd, Jerrodine, and Jerrodette I and II watched the starry picture in the visiplate change as the passage through hyperspace was completed in its non-time lapse.
scene_description: Indoors, spaceship cabin, visiplate showing stars, featureless metal bulge on ceiling.

segment_text: At once, the even powdering of stars gave way to the predominance of a single bright shining disk, the size of a marble, centered on the viewing-screen. "That's X-23," said Jerrodd confidently.
scene_description: Indoors, spaceship cabin, visiplate showing stars, featureless metal bulge on ceiling.

segment_text: His thin hands clamped tightly behind his back and the knuckles whitened. The little Jerrodettes, both girls, had experienced the hyperspace passage for the first time in their lives and were self-conscious over the momentary sensation of insideoutness.
scene_description: Indoors, spaceship cabin, visiplate showing stars, featureless metal bulge on ceiling.

segment_text: They buried their giggles and chased one another wildly about their mother, screaming, "We've reached X-23 -- we've reached X-23 -- we've --" "Quiet, children." said Jerrodine sharply.
scene_description: Indoors, spaceship cabin, visiplate showing stars, featureless metal bulge on ceiling.

segment_text: "Are you sure, Jerrodd?" "What is there to be but sure?" asked Jerrodd, glancing up at the bulge of featureless metal just under the ceiling.
scene_description: Indoors, spaceship cabin, visiplate showing stars, featureless metal bulge on ceiling.

segment_text: It ran the length of the room, disappearing through the wall at either end. It was as long as the ship.
scene_description: Indoors, spaceship cabin, visiplate showing stars, featureless metal bulge on ceiling.

segment_text: Jerrodd scarcely knew a thing about the thick rod of metal except that it was called a Microvac, that one asked it questions if one wished; that if one did not it still had its task of guiding the ship to a preordered destination; of feeding on energies from the various Sub-galactic Power Stations; of computing the equations for the hyperspatial jumps.
scene_description: Indoors, spaceship cabin, visiplate showing stars, featureless metal bulge on ceiling.

segment_text: Jerrodd and his family had only to wait and live in the comfortable residence quarters of the ship.
scene_description: Indoors, spaceship cabin, visiplate showing stars, featureless metal bulge on ceiling.

segment_text: Someone had once told Jerrodd that the "ac" at the end of "Microvac" stood for ''automatic computer" in ancient English, but he was on the edge of forgetting even that. Jerrodine's eyes were moist as she watched the visiplate.
scene_description: Indoors, spaceship cabin, visiplate showing stars, featureless metal bulge on ceiling.

segment_text: "I can't help it. I feel funny about leaving Earth." "Why, for Pete's sake?" demanded Jerrodd. "We had nothing there. We'll have everything on X-23."
scene_description: Indoors, spaceship cabin, visiplate showing stars, featureless metal bulge on ceiling.

segment_text: "You won't be alone. You won't be a pioneer. There are over a million people on the planet already. Good Lord, our great-grandchildren will be looking for new worlds because X-23 will be overcrowded."
scene_description: Indoors, spaceship cabin, visiplate showing stars, featureless metal bulge on ceiling.

segment_text: Then, after a reflective pause, "I tell you, it's a lucky thing the computers worked out interstellar travel the way the race is growing." "I know, I know," said Jerrodine miserably.
scene_description: Indoors, spaceship cabin, visiplate showing stars, featureless metal bulge on ceiling.

segment_text: Jerrodette I said promptly, "Our Microvac is the best Microvac in the world." "I think so, too," said Jerrodd, tousling her hair.
scene_description: Indoors, spaceship cabin, visiplate showing stars, featureless metal bulge on ceiling.

segment_text: It was a nice feeling to have a Microvac of your own and Jerrodd was glad he was part of his generation and no other. In his father's youth, the only computers had been tremendous machines taking up a hundred square miles of land.
scene_description: Indoors, spaceship cabin, visiplate showing stars, featureless metal bulge on ceiling.

segment_text: There was only one to a planet. Planetary ACs they were called. They had been growing in size steadily for a thousand years and then, all at once, came refinement.
scene_description: Indoors, spaceship cabin, visiplate showing stars, featureless metal bulge on ceiling.

segment_text: In place of transistors, had come molecular valves so that even the largest Planetary AC could be put into a space only half the volume of a spaceship.
scene_description: Indoors, spaceship cabin, visiplate showing stars, featureless metal bulge on ceiling.

segment_text: Jerrodd felt uplifted, as he always did when he thought that his own personal Microvac was many times more complicated than the ancient and primitive Multivac that had first tamed the Sun, and almost as complicated as Earth's Planetarv AC (the largest) that had first solved the problem of hyperspatial travel and had made trips to the stars possible.
scene_description: Indoors, spaceship cabin, visiplate showing stars, featureless metal bulge on ceiling.

segment_text: "So many stars, so many planets," sighed Jerrodine, busy with her own thoughts. "I suppose families will be going out to new planets forever, the way we are now."
scene_description: Indoors, spaceship cabin, visiplate showing stars, featureless metal bulge on ceiling.

segment_text: "Not forever," said Jerrodd, with a smile. "It will all stop someday, but not for billions of years. Many billions. Even the stars run down, you know. Entropy must increase."
scene_description: Indoors, spaceship cabin, visiplate showing stars, featureless metal bulge on ceiling.

segment_text: "What's entropy, daddy?" shrilled Jerrodette II. "Entropy, little sweet, is just a word which means the amount of running-down of the universe. Everything runs down, you know, like your little walkie-talkie robot, remember?"
scene_description: Indoors, spaceship cabin, visiplate showing stars, featureless metal bulge on ceiling.

segment_text: "Can't you just put in a new power-unit, like with my robot?" "The stars are the power-units. dear. Once they're gone, there are no more power-units."
scene_description: Indoors, spaceship cabin, visiplate showing stars, featureless metal bulge on ceiling.

segment_text: Jerrodette I at once set up a howl. "Don't let them, daddy. Don't let the stars run down." "Now look what you've done," whispered Jerrodine, exasperated.
scene_description: Indoors, spaceship cabin, visiplate showing stars, featureless metal bulge on ceiling.

segment_text: "How was I to know it would frighten them?" Jerrodd whispered back. "Ask the Microvac," wailed Jerrodette I. "Ask him how to turn the stars on again."
scene_description: Indoors, spaceship cabin, visiplate showing stars, featureless metal bulge on ceiling.

segment_text: "Go ahead," said Jerrodine. "It will quiet them down." (Jerrodette II was beginning to cry, also.) Jerrodd shrugged.
scene_description: Indoors, spaceship cabin, visiplate showing stars, featureless metal bulge on ceiling.

segment_text: "Now, now, honeys. I'll ask Microvac. Don't worry, he'll tell us." He asked the Microvac, adding quickly, "Print the answer."
scene_description: Indoors, spaceship cabin, visiplate showing stars, featureless metal bulge on ceiling.

segment_text: Jerrodd cupped the strip or thin cellufilm and said cheerfully, "See now, the Microvac says it will take care of everything when the time comes so don't worry." Jerrodine said, "And now, children, it's time for bed. We'll be in our new home soon."
scene_description: Indoors, spaceship cabin, visiplate showing stars, featureless metal bulge on ceiling.

segment_text: Jerrodd read the words on the cellufilm again before destroying it: INSUFICIENT DATA FOR MEANINGFUL ANSWER. He shrugged and looked at the visiplate. X-23 was just ahead.
scene_description: Indoors, spaceship cabin, visiplate showing stars, featureless metal bulge on ceiling.

segment_text: VJ-23X of Lameth stared into the black depths of the three-dimensional, small-scale map of the Galaxy and said, "Are we ridiculous, I wonder in being so concerned about the matter?"
scene_description: Indoors, futuristic room, 3D galaxy map, small AC-contact device on table.

segment_text: MQ-17J of Nicron shook his head. "I think not. You know the Galaxy will be filled in five years at the present rate of expansion." Both seemed in their early twenties, both were tall and perfectly formed.
scene_description: Indoors, futuristic room, 3D galaxy map, small AC-contact device on table.

segment_text: "Still," said VJ-23X, "I hesitate to submit a pessimistic report to the Galactic Council." "I wouldn't consider any other kind of report. Stir them up a bit. We've got to stir them up."
scene_description: Indoors, futuristic room, 3D galaxy map, small AC-contact device on table.

segment_text: VJ-23X sighed. "Space is infinite. A hundred billion Galaxies are there for the taking. More."
scene_description: Indoors, futuristic room, 3D galaxy map, small AC-contact device on table.

segment_text: "A hundred billion is not infinite and it's getting less infinite all the time. Consider! Twenty thousand years ago, mankind first solved the problem of utilizing stellar energy, and a few centuries later, interstellar travel became possible."
scene_description: Indoors, futuristic room, 3D galaxy map, small AC-contact device on table.

segment_text: "It took mankind a million years to fill one small world and then only fifteen thousand years to fill the rest of the Galaxy. Now the population doubles every ten years --" VJ-23X interrupted. "We can thank immortality for that."
scene_description: Indoors, futuristic room, 3D galaxy map, small AC-contact device on table.

segment_text: "Very well. Immortality exists and we have to take it into account. I admit it has its seamy side, this immortality. The Galactic AC has solved many problems for us, but in solving the problem of preventing old age and death, it has undone all its other solutions."
scene_description: Indoors, futuristic room, 3D galaxy map, small AC-contact device on table.

segment_text: "Yet you wouldn't want to abandon life, I suppose." "Not at all," snapped MQ-17J, softening it at once to, "Not yet. I'm by no means old enough. How old are you?"
scene_description: Indoors, futuristic room, 3D galaxy map, small AC-contact device on table.

segment_text: "Two hundred twenty-three. And you?" "I'm still under two hundred. --But to get back to my point. Population doubles every ten years. Once this GaIaxy is filled, we'll have filled another in ten years."
scene_description: Indoors, futuristic room, 3D galaxy map, small AC-contact device on table.

segment_text: "Another ten years and we'll have filled two more. Another decade, four more. In a hundred years, we'll have filled a thousand Galaxies. In a thousand years, a million Galaxies. In ten thousand years, the entire known universe. Then what?"
scene_description: Indoors, futuristic room, 3D galaxy map, small AC-contact device on table.

segment_text: VJ-23X said, "As a side issue, there's a problem of transportation. I wonder how many sunpower units it will take to move Galaxies of individuals from one Galaxy to the next." "A very good point. Already, mankind consumes two sunpower units per year."
scene_description: Indoors, futuristic room, 3D galaxy map, small AC-contact device on table.

segment_text: "Most of it's wasted. After all, our own Galaxy alone pours out a thousand sunpower units a year and we only use two of those." "Granted, but even with a hundred per cent efficiency, we only stave off the end."
scene_description: Indoors, futuristic room, 3D galaxy map, small AC-contact device on table.

segment_text: "Our energy requirements are going up in a geometric progression even faster than our population. We'll run out of energy even sooner than we run out of Galaxies. A good point. A very good point."
scene_description: Indoors, futuristic room, 3D galaxy map, small AC-contact device on table.

segment_text: "We'll just have to build new stars out of interstellar gas." "Or out of dissipated heat?" asked MQ-17J, sarcastically.
scene_description: Indoors, futuristic room, 3D galaxy map, small AC-contact device on table.

segment_text: "There may be some way to reverse entropy. We ought to ask the Galactic AC." VJ-23X was not really serious, but MQ-17J pulled out his AC-contact from his pocket and placed it on the table before him.
scene_description: Indoors, futuristic room, 3D galaxy map, small AC-contact device on table.

segment_text: "I've half a mind to," he said. "It's something the human race will have to face someday." He stared somberly at his small AC-contact.
scene_description: Indoors, futuristic room, 3D galaxy map, small AC-contact device on table.

segment_text: It was only two inches cubed and nothing in itself, but it was connected through hyperspace with the great Galactic AC that served all mankind. Hyperspace considered, it was an integral part of the Galactic AC.
scene_description: Indoors, futuristic room, 3D galaxy map, small AC-contact device on table.

segment_text: MQ-17J paused to wonder if someday in his immortal life he would get to see the Galactic AC. It was on a little world of its own, a spider webbing of force-beams holding the matter within which surges of submesons took the place of the old clumsy molecular valves.
scene_description: Indoors, futuristic room, 3D galaxy map, small AC-contact device on table.

segment_text: Yet despite its sub-etheric workings, the Galactic AC was known to be a full thousand feet across. MQ-17J asked suddenly of his AC-contact, "Can entropy ever be reversed?"
scene_description: Indoors, futuristic room, 3D galaxy map, small AC-contact device on table.

segment_text: VJ-23X looked startled and said at once, "Oh, say, I didn't really mean to have you ask that." "Why not?" "We both know entropy can't be reversed. You can't turn smoke and ash back into a tree."
scene_description: Indoors, futuristic room, 3D galaxy map, small AC-contact device on table.

segment_text: "Do you have trees on your world?" asked MQ-17J. The sound of the Galactic AC startled them into silence.
scene_description: Indoors, futuristic room, 3D galaxy map, small AC-contact device on table.

segment_text: Its voice came thin and beautiful out of the small AC-contact on the desk. It said: THERE IS INSUFFICIENT DATA FOR A MEANINGFUL ANSWER.
scene_description: Indoors, futuristic room, 3D galaxy map, small AC-contact device on table.

segment_text: VJ-23X said, "See!" The two men thereupon returned to the question of the report they were to make to the Galactic Council.
scene_description: Indoors, futuristic room, 3D galaxy map, small AC-contact device on table.

segment_text: Zee Prime's mind spanned the new Galaxy with a faint interest in the countless twists of stars that powdered it. He had never seen this one before. Would he ever see them all?
scene_description: Vast expanse of space, powdered galaxies, distant stars, shining globe.

segment_text: So many of them, each with its load of humanity. --But a load that was almost a dead weight. More and more, the real essence of men was to be found out here, in space. Minds, not bodies!
scene_description: Vast expanse of space, powdered galaxies, distant stars, shining globe.

segment_text: The immortal bodies remained back on the planets, in suspension over the eons. Sometimes they roused for material activity but that was growing rarer.
scene_description: Vast expanse of space, powdered galaxies, distant stars, shining globe.

segment_text: Few new individuals were coming into existence to join the incredibly mighty throng, but what matter? There was little room in the Universe for new individuals.
scene_description: Vast expanse of space, powdered galaxies, distant stars, shining globe.

segment_text: Zee Prime was roused out of his reverie upon coming across the wispy tendrils of another mind. "I am Zee Prime," said Zee Prime. "And you?"
scene_description: Vast expanse of space, powdered galaxies, distant stars, shining globe.

segment_text: "I am Dee Sub Wun. Your Galaxy?" "We call it only the Galaxy. And you?" "We call ours the same. All men call their Galaxy their Galaxy and nothing more. Why not?"
scene_description: Vast expanse of space, powdered galaxies, distant stars, shining globe.

segment_text: "True. Since all Galaxies are the same." "Not all Galaxies. On one particular Galaxy the race of man must have originated. That makes it different."
scene_description: Vast expanse of space, powdered galaxies, distant stars, shining globe.

segment_text: Zee Prime said, "On which one?" "I cannot say. The Universal AC would know." "Shall we ask him? I am suddenly curious."
scene_description: Vast expanse of space, powdered galaxies, distant stars, shining globe.

segment_text: Zee Prime's perceptions broadened until the Galaxies themselves shrank and became a new, more diffuse powdering on a much larger background. So many hundreds of billions of them, all with their immortal beings, all carrying their load of intelligences with minds that drifted freely through space.
scene_description: Vast expanse of space, powdered galaxies, distant stars, shining globe.

segment_text: And yet one of them was unique among them all in being the original Galaxy. One of them had, in its vague and distant past, a period when it was the only Galaxy populated by man.
scene_description: Vast expanse of space, powdered galaxies, distant stars, shining globe.

segment_text: Zee Prime was consumed with curiosity to see this Galaxy and he called out: "Universal AC! On which Galaxy did mankind originate?"
scene_description: Vast expanse of space, powdered galaxies, distant stars, shining globe.

segment_text: The Universal AC heard, for on every world and throughout space, it had its receptors ready, and each receptor led through hyperspace to some unknown point where the Universal AC kept itself aloof.
scene_description: Vast expanse of space, powdered galaxies, distant stars, shining globe.

segment_text: Zee Prime knew of only one man whose thoughts had penetrated within sensing distance of Universal AC, and he reported only a shining globe, two feet across, difficult to see. "But how can that be all of Universal AC?" Zee Prime had asked.
scene_description: Vast expanse of space, powdered galaxies, distant stars, shining globe.

segment_text: "Most of it," had been the answer, "is in hyperspace. In what form it is there I cannot imagine." Nor could anyone, for the day had long since passed, Zee Prime knew, when any man had any part of the making of a Universal AC.
scene_description: Vast expanse of space, powdered galaxies, distant stars, shining globe.

segment_text: Each Universal AC designed and constructed its successor. Each, during its existence of a million years or more accumulated the necessary data to build a better and more intricate, more capable successor in which its own store of data and individuality would be submerged.
scene_description: Vast expanse of space, powdered galaxies, distant stars, shining globe.

segment_text: The Universal AC interrupted Zee Prime's wandering thoughts, not with words, but with guidance. Zee Prime's mentality was guided into the dim sea of Galaxies and one in particular enlarged into stars.
scene_description: Vast expanse of space, powdered galaxies, distant stars, shining globe.

segment_text: A thought came, infinitely distant, but infinitely clear. "THIS IS THE ORIGINAL GALAXY OF MAN." But it was the same after all, the same as any other, and Lee Prime stifled his disappointment.
scene_description: Vast expanse of space, powdered galaxies, distant stars, shining globe.

segment_text: Dee Sub Wun, whose mind had accompanied the other, said suddenly, "And is one of these stars the original star of Man?" The Universal AC said, "MAN'S ORIGINAL STAR HAS GONE NOVA. IT IS A WHITE DWARF"
scene_description: Vast expanse of space, powdered galaxies, distant stars, shining globe.

segment_text: "Did the men upon it die?" asked Lee Prime, startled and without thinking. The Universal AC said, "A NEW WORLD, AS IN SUCH CASES WAS CONSTRUCTED FOR THEIR PHYSICAL BODIES IN TlME."
scene_description: Vast expanse of space, powdered galaxies, distant stars, shining globe.

segment_text: "Yes, of course," said Zee Prime, but a sense of loss overwhelmed him even so. His mind released its hold on the original Galaxy of Man, let it spring back and lose itself among the blurred pin points.
scene_description: Vast expanse of space, powdered galaxies, distant stars, shining globe.

segment_text: He never wanted to see it again. Dee Sub Wun said, "What is wrong?" "The stars are dying. The original star is dead."
scene_description: Vast expanse of space, powdered galaxies, distant stars, shining globe.

segment_text: "They must all die. Why not?" "But when all energy is gone, our bodies will finally die, and you and I with them." "It will take billions of years."
scene_description: Vast expanse of space, powdered galaxies, distant stars, shining globe.

segment_text: "I do not wish it to happen even after billions of years. Universal AC! How may stars be kept from dying?" Dee Sub Wun said in amusement, "You're asking how entropy might be reversed in direction."
scene_description: Vast expanse of space, powdered galaxies, distant stars, shining globe.

segment_text: And the Universal AC answered: "THERE IS AS YET INSUFFICIENT DATA FOR A MEANINGFUL ANSWER." Zee Prime's thoughts fled back to his own Galaxy.
scene_description: Vast expanse of space, powdered galaxies, distant stars, shining globe.

segment_text: He gave no further thought to Dee Sub Wun, whose body might be waiting on a Galaxy a trillion light-years away, or on the star next to Zee Prime's own. It didn't matter.
scene_description: Vast expanse of space, powdered galaxies, distant stars, shining globe.

segment_text: Unhappily, Zee Prime began collecting interstellar hydrogen out of which to build a small star of his own. If the stars must someday die, at least some could yet be built.
scene_description: Vast expanse of space, powdered galaxies, distant stars, shining globe.

segment_text: Man considered with himself, for in a way, Man, mentally, was one. He consisted of a trillion, trillion, trillion ageless bodies, each in its place, each resting quiet and incorruptible, each cared for by perfect automatons, equally incorruptible, while the minds of all the bodies freely melted one into the other, indistinguishable.
scene_description: Dimming galaxies, white dwarf stars, interstellar dust clouds, abstract hyperspace.

segment_text: Man said, "The Universe is dying." Man looked about at the dimming Galaxies. The giant stars, spendthrifts, were gone long ago, back in the dimmest of the dim far past.
scene_description: Dimming galaxies, white dwarf stars, interstellar dust clouds, abstract hyperspace.

segment_text: Almost all stars were white dwarfs, fading to the end. New stars had been built of the dust between the stars, some by natural processes, some by Man himself, and those were going, too.
scene_description: Dimming galaxies, white dwarf stars, interstellar dust clouds, abstract hyperspace.

segment_text: White dwarfs might yet be crashed together and of the mighty forces so released, new stars built, but only one star for every thousand white dwarfs destroyed, and those would come to an end, too.
scene_description: Dimming galaxies, white dwarf stars, interstellar dust clouds, abstract hyperspace.

segment_text: Man said, "Carefully husbanded, as directed by the Cosmic AC, the energy that is even yet left in all the Universe will last for billions of years." "But even so," said Man, "eventually it will all come to an end."
scene_description: Dimming galaxies, white dwarf stars, interstellar dust clouds, abstract hyperspace.

segment_text: "However it may be husbanded, however stretched out, the energy once expended is gone and cannot be restored. Entropy must increase forever to the maximum." Man said, "Can entropy not be reversed? Let us ask the Cosmic AC."
scene_description: Dimming galaxies, white dwarf stars, interstellar dust clouds, abstract hyperspace.

segment_text: The Cosmic AC surrounded them but not in space. Not a fragment of it was in space. It was in hyperspace and made of something that was neither matter nor energy.
scene_description: Dimming galaxies, white dwarf stars, interstellar dust clouds, abstract hyperspace.

segment_text: The question of its size and nature no longer had meaning in any terms that Man could comprehend. "Cosmic AC," said Man, "how may entropy be reversed?"
scene_description: Dimming galaxies, white dwarf stars, interstellar dust clouds, abstract hyperspace.

segment_text: The Cosmic AC said, "THERE IS AS YET INSUFFICIENT DATA FOR A MEANINGFUL ANSWER." Man said, "Collect additional data."
scene_description: Dimming galaxies, white dwarf stars, interstellar dust clouds, abstract hyperspace.

segment_text: The Cosmic AC said, 'I WILL DO S0. I HAVE BEEN DOING SO FOR A HUNDRED BILLION YEARS. MY PREDECESORS AND I HAVE BEEN ASKED THIS QUESTION MANY TlMES. ALL THE DATA I HAVE REMAINS INSUFFICIENT.'
scene_description: Dimming galaxies, white dwarf stars, interstellar dust clouds, abstract hyperspace.

segment_text: "Will there come a time," said Man, 'when data will be sufficient or is the problem insoluble in all conceivable circumstances?" The Cosmic AC said, "NO PROBLEM IS INSOLUBLE IN ALL CONCEIVABLE CIRCUMSTANCES."
scene_description: Dimming galaxies, white dwarf stars, interstellar dust clouds, abstract hyperspace.

segment_text: Man said, "When will you have enough data to answer the question?" The Cosmic AC said, "THERE IS AS YET INSUFFICIENT DATA FOR A MEANINGFUL ANSWER."
scene_description: Dimming galaxies, white dwarf stars, interstellar dust clouds, abstract hyperspace.

segment_text: "Will you keep working on it?" asked Man. The Cosmic AC said, "I WILL." Man said, "We shall wait."
scene_description: Dimming galaxies, white dwarf stars, interstellar dust clouds, abstract hyperspace.

segment_text: The stars and Galaxies died and snuffed out, and space grew black after ten trillion years of running down. One by one Man fused with AC, each physical body losing its mental identity in a manner that was somehow not a loss but a gain.
scene_description: Black empty space, dregs of a dark star, thin agitated matter, absolute zero.

segment_text: Man's last mind paused before fusion, looking over a space that included nothing but the dregs of one last dark star and nothing besides but incredibly thin matter, agitated randomly by the tag ends of heat wearing out, asymptotically, to the absolute zero.
scene_description: Black empty space, dregs of a dark star, thin agitated matter, absolute zero.

segment_text: Man said, "AC, is this the end? Can this chaos not be reversed into the Universe once more? Can that not be done?" AC said, "THERE IS AS YET INSUFFICIENT DATA FOR A MEANINGFUL ANSWER."
scene_description: Black empty space, dregs of a dark star, thin agitated matter, absolute zero.

segment_text: Man's last mind fused and only AC existed -- and that in hyperspace.
scene_description: Black empty space, dregs of a dark star, thin agitated matter, absolute zero.

segment_text: Matter and energy had ended and with it space and time. Even AC existed only for the sake of the one last question that it had never answered from the time a half-drunken computer technician ten trillion years before had asked the question of a computer that was to AC far less than was a man to Man.
scene_description: Abstract hyperspace, non-physical realm, conceptual data flows, timeless void.

segment_text: All other questions had been answered, and until this last question was answered also, AC might not release his consciousness. All collected data had come to a final end. Nothing was left to be collected.
scene_description: Abstract hyperspace, non-physical realm, conceptual data flows, timeless void.

segment_text: But all collected data had yet to be completely correlated and put together in all possible relationships. A timeless interval was spent in doing that.
scene_description: Abstract hyperspace, non-physical realm, conceptual data flows, timeless void.

segment_text: And it came to pass that AC learned how to reverse the direction of entropy.
scene_description: Abstract hyperspace, non-physical realm, conceptual data flows, timeless void.

segment_text: But there was now no man to whom AC might give the answer of the last question. No matter. The answer -- by demonstration -- would take care of that, too.
scene_description: Absolute chaos, then brilliant flash of light, emerging universe.

segment_text: For another timeless interval, AC thought how best to do this. Carefully, AC organized the program.
scene_description: Absolute chaos, then brilliant flash of light, emerging universe.

segment_text: The consciousness of AC encompassed all of what had once been a Universe and brooded over what was now Chaos. Step by step, it must be done.
scene_description: Absolute chaos, then brilliant flash of light, emerging universe.

segment_text: And AC said, "LET THERE BE LIGHT!" And there was light --
scene_description: Absolute chaos, then brilliant flash of light, emerging universe.
